entry.title: Combined summary - Drivechain proposal using OP_COUNT_ACKS
entry.summary: Sergio Demian Lerner, co-founder of RSK, has proposed a new opcode called OP_COUNT_ACKS to count acknowledgement tags in coinbase fields. The proposal has several properties in mind including interoperability with the scripting system, zero risk of invalidating a block, no additional computation during blockchain management and re-organization, and strong protection from DoS attacks. Lerner will be discussing the design rationale, improvements, changes and ideas at the upcoming Scaling Bitcoin event.The discussion involves proposals on how to improve the Bitcoin protocol through a softfork. One proposal suggests using an unused code instead of OP_NOPx, which should be reserved for simple VERIFY-type codes that do not write to the stack. Another proposal considers the use of a new witness version and an additional field in the witness to indicate script version. Additionally, there are concerns regarding the potential shortage of poll space due to an artificial limit.In an email exchange between Sergio Demian Lerner and Peter Todd, Lerner questioned Todd's down vote of his Rootstock proposal, which would benefit the Bitcoin community. Todd had allegedly attacked Lerner personally without basis, prompting Lerner to suggest that Rootstock adopt a legally binding patent pledge/license to continue collaborating. Lerner recommended that Rootstock adopt the Defensive Patent License (DPL), which he planned to do for his own consulting company. The email thread is a technical discussion and not political. Peter Todd suggests that Rootstock should adopt a legally binding patent pledge or license, such as the Defensive Patent License (DPL), to rectify any potential patent issues. He mentions that he will be doing so for his own consulting company. If Rootstock does not plan on obtaining offensive patents, then there should be no issue with adopting the DPL. Todd requests that this issue be fixed so that collaboration can continue to improve Bitcoin.From the given context, it is not clear what rule is being referred to. However, the discussion seems to be about implementing decentralised sidechains. The process of redemption from a side chain involves two phases. Firstly, the person unpegging the funds provides proof that they have locked the funds on the side chain, and are eligible to withdraw the funds, along with putting up a bounty. Secondly, there is a time-locked period where others can collect the bounty by providing a fraud proof that the locked funds given in the proof have actually been double spent.In an email thread on the Bitcoin-dev mailing list, Russell O'Connor argued that a proposal to use OP_COUNT_ACKS in transactions was objectionable as it could cause transactions to fluctuate between acceptable and unacceptable with no double spend occurring. However, he acknowledged that such transactions were less likely to be used for denial-of-service (DoS) attacks as they could only be included by miners. Transactions redeeming outputs containing or referencing OP_COUNT_ACKS are not broadcast by the network and can only be included by miners. Therefore, O'Connor saw no issue with invalidating transactions after the liveness time expires, as without an expiration, polls could last forever and fail to provide DoS protection for block validation.The email thread also discusses the proposed drivechain for RSK (also known as Rootstock), a two-way pegged blockchain that allows for risk-less Bitcoin extensibility via sidechains/drivechains. The proposed system includes a new opcode, OP_COUNT_ACKS, which counts acks and nacks tags in coinbase fields and pushes the resulting totals onto the script stack. However, there is concern about the validity of transactions being dependent on the block they are included in. The added check lock time and check sequence number operations were carefully constructed to ensure this property. In a related discussion, Russell O'Connor expressed concern that this would result in transactions being invalid in subsequent blocks, which would break the monotonicity rule for transaction validity. While it's unclear if decentralised sidechains can be implemented without breaking this rule, Luke argued that it may be acceptable as the only way the transaction would become invalid is through the equivalent of a double-spend.Sergio also expressed his doubts over any proposals from an individual or colleagues who have a history of patenting Bitcoin consensus relevant technology, which he believes to be a serious threat to decentralization. He suggested that the dangerous and unethical behavior needs to be rectified in a convincing, legally binding way and proposed looking into Blockstream's patent pledges for a way forward. Lerner NACKed the proposal on the basis of the history of patenting. Concerns were raised regarding the possibility of any encumbrances on a proposal that would preclude its use in the Bitcoin project. The concern stemmed from the fact that pending patents are not publicly visible, and the BIP process does not require patent disclosure. However, it was suggested that providing a voluntary disclosure of patents with a free license to such patents could be an alternative solution to resolve patent concerns if Rootstock is not prepared to adopt a defensive patent strategy in general.In
